course_title: Advanced Therapy Skills: Working with Complex and Non-traditional Clients

learning_outcomes.description: Critically reflect on key knowledge about complex clinical problems and particular needs and characteristics of non-traditional clinical populations
Practice advanced skills required for the effective management of complex clinical challenges (motivational interviewing, repair of alliance ruptured, risk management, etc.)
Practice specific skills required for the effective treatment of non-traditional clients

assessments.task_description:
Before the tutorial time you should post in the Learn.UQ (Blackboard) online discussion board a response to the questions identified for that week’s tutorial based on the readings associated with that tutorial. Post should be 300 words long (10% tolerance), use content of the readings to address the questions, and show evidence of your reflections.

Please consult with staff for legitimate use of AI for the online discussion board. The course coordinator or tutor might organise an oral examination of the online discussion board to confirm authorship of the posts and verify learnings acquired through its elaboration. Please check https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/tools-and-techniques/ai-student-hub/ai-for-assessment

Criteria & Marking:

  1. Online entries are original and show evidence that the readings have been analysed in a thoughtful and reflective manner.
  2. Online entries have addressed the set of questions using a professional approach to learning.
  3. There are 10 online entries posted on time, within the word limit, free of spelling and grammatical errors and that demonstrate appropriate engagement with the task.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Post in Discussion Board at the course Blackboard website on Learn.UQ.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Please refer to the UQ policy on late submission.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Lead tutorial session and discussion with tutorial group
assessments.due_date:
12/03/2026 - 28/05/2026

Presentation can't be rescheduled due to fixed calendar of tutorial topics and readings.

Students not presenting on due date having an approved extension will be provided with a date to attend an oral exam outside tutorial times as replacement for the oral presentation.
assessments.task_description:
In this activity you will lead the tutorial session as if you were delivering a brief professional development presentation at work. Your presentation will be about the one complex mental health problem and how it is addressed by two contending therapeutic interventions (adjustments to treatment proposed by two contending therapeutic traditions for a non-traditional clinical population could be the topic too). You should be able to draw on the strengths and weaknesses of each approach, and their similarities and differences. You should also be able to exemplify how an aspect of these interventions can be applied based on your clinical practice, and lastly, you should lead a discussion with the tutorial group to expand on issues identified during your presentation and connect the topic with other students' practice. You can use PowerPoint slides to support your presentation.

At the start of the semester the tutor will determine with the students the roster of presentations for the semester based on the list of tutorial topics. Students might seek support from tutors or course coordinator for the preparation of their presentation.

During your presentation you should:

a) Define one complex clinical problem or non-traditional clinical population, including characteristics, history and research finding about prevalence, burden of illness, etc.

b) Critically discuss two contending perspectives/therapeutic interventions for this clinical problem or clinical population, drawing on strengths and weaknesses, similarities and differences.

c) Reflect on how these therapeutic interventions might or not be applicable to your current practice.

d) Leads tutorial session, fostering engagement and active participation of tutorial group in the discussion of the topic. 

e) Present a clear, well organised and visually appealing presentation (you might use PowerPoint slides), with a suggested time distribution of 15-20 minutes for the presentation and 10-15 minutes for leading a discussion with the group. The exact duration of the presentation will be confirmed by the tutor based on the number of students.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Therapeutic models for complex clinical problems
assessments.task_description:
The management of complex clinical problems and the adjustments to practice for non-traditional populations are understood in different ways by diverse therapeutic traditions, leading to differences in practice. For this essay you are asked to refer to one complex clinical problem or one particular non-traditional population, comparing how this problem or population is understood and treated by two different therapeutic traditions, proposing a comparative analysis. Identify implications for clinical practice of the differences you drew. Also provide a clinical example from your practice to illustrate these implications.

Please consult with staff for legitimate use of AI for this essay. The course coordinator or tutor might organise an oral examination of the essay to confirm authorship of the essay and verify learnings acquired through its elaboration. Please check https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/tools-and-techniques/ai-student-hub/ai-for-assessment

Criteria & Marking:

  1. Clearly defines a clinical problem or a non-traditional population, referring to its importance according to theory and research
  2. Presents how this problem is managed, or this population is addressed by two contending traditions, identifying similarities and differences in these conceptualisations
  3. Discusses possible implications to clinical practice that derive from the identified differences, and illustrates the implications using an example from own clinical practice
  4. Writing is clear and grammatically sound, uses well-chosen and correctly spelt vocabulary; referencing and citation format is standard and the number of words (excluding references) is +/- 10% of the specified limit: text is well organised and visual layout is clear
assessments.submission_guidelines: This essay has to be submitted through the Turnitin link provided in the LearnUQ (Blackboard) site
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Please refer to the UQ policy on late submission.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
T2: Enhancing engagement and motivation to therapy

What factors underpin low motivation to change? What factors hinder engagement? What is helpful to work through these challenges?

Art Therapy reading: Jung Min Cho

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: T2: Enhancing engagement and motivation to therapy
learning_activities.topic_description: T2: Enhancing engagement and motivation to therapy What factors underpin low motivation to change? What factors hinder engagement? What is helpful to work through these challenges? Art Therapy reading: Jung Min Cho

learning_activities.topic:
T3: Repairing alliance ruptures

What factors lead to alliance ruptures or relational impasses? What is helpful to repair or manage ruptures?

Art Therapy readings: Watson et al; Crane & Byrne.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: T3: Repairing alliance ruptures What factors lead to alliance ruptures or relational impasses? What is helpful to repair or manage ruptures? Art Therapy readings: Watson et al; Crane & Byrne.

learning_activities.topic:
T4: Understanding emotional dysregulation and crises

What leads to these states and how can we understand their occurrence? When are they normal and when not? Whatﾒs helpful to support someone going through an affect storm, dysregulation or an emotional crisis?

Art Therapy readings: Huss et al; Haeyen, S. Chap 6

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: T4: Understanding emotional dysregulation and crises What leads to these states and how can we understand their occurrence? When are they normal and when not? Whatﾒs helpful to support someone going through an affect storm, dysregulation or an emotional crisis? Art Therapy readings: Huss et al; Haeyen, S. Chap 6

learning_activities.topic:
T5: Managing DSH & suicide risk in therapy

What leads to deliberate self-harm? What leads to suicidal risk? What is helpful working with people through these difficulties? Whatﾒs the emotional impact for clinician working with these risks?

Art Therapy readings: Harnden, B.; Rasmussen et al

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: T5: Managing DSH & suicide risk in therapy
learning_activities.topic_description: T5: Managing DSH & suicide risk in therapy What leads to deliberate self-harm? What leads to suicidal risk? What is helpful working with people through these difficulties? Whatﾒs the emotional impact for clinician working with these risks? Art Therapy readings: Harnden, B.; Rasmussen et al

learning_activities.topic:
T6: Managing aggression & violence risk

What leads to aggressive and violent behaviour? How is it linked to mental health? When is anger/aggression normal, and when can its absence be seen as a problem? How does the risk of violence impact the clinician?

Art Therapy readings: Gussak

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: T6: Managing aggression & violence risk What leads to aggressive and violent behaviour? How is it linked to mental health? When is anger/aggression normal, and when can its absence be seen as a problem? How does the risk of violence impact the clinician? Art Therapy readings: Gussak

learning_activities.topic:
T7: Working with personality disorders

What leads to the development of personality disorders? What kind of therapeutic approaches are helpful for borderline personality disorders? What's the impact over the therapist of working with severe personality disorders? What are other relevant personality disorders and what modalities of treatment are helpful?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: T7: Working with personality disorders What leads to the development of personality disorders? What kind of therapeutic approaches are helpful for borderline personality disorders? What's the impact over the therapist of working with severe personality disorders? What are other relevant personality disorders and what modalities of treatment are helpful?

learning_activities.topic:
T8: Working with psychosis

Are psychosis and schizophrenia synonyms? What do we know about predisposition and perpetuating factors for psychotic conditions? What kind of psychotherapeutic treatments are available for people with psychosis, and what do they pursue?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: T8: Working with psychosis Are psychosis and schizophrenia synonyms? What do we know about predisposition and perpetuating factors for psychotic conditions? What kind of psychotherapeutic treatments are available for people with psychosis, and what do they pursue?

learning_activities.topic:
T9: Working with PTSD and other complex presentations

What is trauma, PTSD and complex PTSD? What psychotherapeutic models are helpful for these conditions, and what are some commonalities between treatment modalities?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: T9: Working with PTSD and other complex presentations
learning_activities.topic_description: T9: Working with PTSD and other complex presentations What is trauma, PTSD and complex PTSD? What psychotherapeutic models are helpful for these conditions, and what are some commonalities between treatment modalities?

learning_activities.topic:
T10: Working with somatic disorder and eating disorders

How can psychotherapy help people with somatic/conversion disorders? What commonalities are there between effective approaches to somatic disorders? What do we know about the predisposing and perpetuating factors for eating disorders? What approaches are helpful to treat people with eating disorders?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

What approaches are helpful to treat people with eating disorders?

learning_activities.topic:
T11: Working with first nations and CALD populations

What principles or approaches are useful to work effectively and respectfully with first nations and CALD populations? What are the main clinical challenges faced by refugees? What is helpful to support these populations?

Learning outcomes: L01, L03

learning_activities.topic:
T12: Working with other non-traditional populations

What kind of mental health challenges are faced by LGBTIQ peoples? What are some psychotherapeutic approaches to these challenges? What are some challenges faced by people with disabilities and what approaches are helpful to support these populations?

Learning outcomes: L01, L03
